titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Friday April 13th: 1792. My Resolution of journalizing, which I adopted perhaps for the fiftieth time more than twelve months since, was like all my other resolutions of any consequence productive only of a few pages of writing, and by looking at the last page it will be seen that more than eleven months have elapsed since I put pen to this paper.— And why should I?— Events perfectly trivial, or if rising in the smallest degree beyond the level of insipidity, always unsuccessfull; a continued series of painful occurrences, and mortifying reflections, why should I give them a stability and duration which happily they cannot naturally have, by recording them. The last year of my life has not been without its instruction. But the difficulties, and perplexities under which I laboured twelve months since still continue; and are increased by the consideration that I have now gone through another annual revolution in my progress to the grave, without advancing a step in my career, as it relates to this world.— However it is of no purpose to complain, and whine & fret, and murmur at the moral government of the world.— I will say as little of myself as I can and henceforth, endeavour to be more philosophical, than I have been able to be hitherto. Improvement is my object;—the occasion is great;—the room for it unlimited, the capacity—(me miserum!) deplorably narrow—the benefits to be derived from all my exertions, (if I judge of my future from my past success)—nothing. But it is at all Events labouring to answer the purpose for which I was created,
and I hope therefore that I shall not be discouraged in the pursuit. If I should never reap the reward of my application, at least it will never injure me; the occupation is innocent: it can never be productive of evil either to myself, or to those around me.

Saturday April 14th: 1792. For several years past, I have endeavoured to vary my studies so that I might avoid in some degree the tediousness of a long continued application to one subject, and that my different studies might succeed one another so as to afford a sort of relaxation the one to the other. I have devoted the forenoon to those studies which are more immediately connected with my profession, and reserved the latter part of the day for mental amusement, for the investigation of those parts of Science, which have no other relation to the Law, than the universal chain, the commune vinculum, which links together every part of the moral world.— This day however I have read no Law. The morning, was principally employed in business.— In the afternoon pursuant to a resolution long since adopted, I read an Oration of Cicero. Fully perswaded, that the clearest and most copious streams of Science, flow only from the fountains of Antiquity, I have often determined, to make myself a complete master at least of all the Latin classics: but my imperfect acquaintance even with that language, and the perpetual avocations which interrupt my pursuit combining together, prevent the Execution of a design from which I believe I should derive some advantages. I did hope that by the attention which I had determined to bestow, I should improve my knowledge of the Latin so as to render it perfectly familiar to me: but in vain. I can read but very slowly and therefore I cannot read with pleasure. In the course of the last winter I went through the Annals &
the History of Tacitus, and derived much satisfaction from the perusal. I have since then, again taken up the Orations of Cicero, and intend if possible to understand them thoroughly in the original. This afternoon. I began upon the Philippics, against Antony. Read the first; and part of the second. The progress of his resentment is strongly marked in the different style of the two Orations: in the first he speaks with moderation; calls himself the friend of Antony; pays him several handsome compliments; and only complains with great decency, and without any of the opprobrious epithets contained in the second, of the threats which Antony had uttered against him the day before: that he would send workmen to pull down his House for absenting himself from the Senate. Complains of the frauds practiced by Antony under the pretence of establishing the acts of Caesar; and recommends to him & his colleague Dolabella, then consul, to pursue the true interest of the republic and their own glory; but in the second he attacks with great vehemence the life & manners of Antony, with whom from that period he did not keep any measures at all. After justifying himself from the censures which Antony had cast upon him in a previous Speech, he examines the whole public & private life of his adversary, and charges him with almost every crime that can disgrace human Nature. This Oration was among the ancients considered as the master-piece of Cicero, and was the occasion of his Death, by making Antony, altogether implacable.

Monday April 16th: 1792. I attended public worship yesterday, and heard Dr: Lathrop in the morning, & Mr: Clarke in the afternoon. Nothing however very peculiar was suggested to me by either of their discourses. After meeting I took a solitary walk to Roxbury, and returned home to tea. The Eveg: I spent at Mr: Smith’s. In the way of reading I finished Lord Kaims’s Elements of Criticism; which I borrowed sometime since of Mr: Clarke, and with which I am much pleased— His System appears to me to be rather too metaphysical; rather too abstracted, and his principles in some instances rather fanciful: neither does he constantly attend to his own principles—but the idea of deriving all critical regulations from the dispositions inherent in human Nature, is just and ingenious; his applications are sometimes happy, but they are sometimes too refined, and if I may venture to oppose my own sentiments to those which he dictates, sometimes unjust. The book is however, certainly worth a second reading, which I shall bestow upon it if I should ever have the necessary leisure.

This forenoon I was principally employed upon business, & read no Law. A couple of writs which I had sent into the County of Hampshire, were returned to me by the Sheriff not served, as received them too late for the purpose. I altered them accordingly to July term, & sent them away again. filled two other writs—and had some conversation with Dr: Jennison, who applied to me upon business, and who will call on me again next Monday.— In the afternoon I finished the second Philippic of Cicero. The particular attention which I have paid for sometime past to this writer, has been because he is generally viewed, as one of the first Orators of Antiquity, and because his Orations are
recommended as models for all young men, engaged in a profession of which public speaking forms an essential part. Yet the style of Oratory for which he is so highly celebrated seems to be widely different from that which would ensure success at the Bar in our time.— There could not indeed under the present state of Society be any occasion upon which such discourses as the Philippics would be proper or even tolerable— A personal invective of one public man against another in a deliberative assembly would be ill received at this day. Such however, and nothing more is this boasted divine Philippic— In which the Orator begins by answering the charges of a similar oration previously delivered by Antony against himself: and after justifying his own conduct, he attacks Antony in his private as well as in his public character; reproaches him for the licentiousness of his youth; for his convivial indiscretions, for his amorous indulgences, and for his extravagant expences, no less than for his violations of the Constitution, and his fraud, rapine and violence in the public offices of State. The whole force of his Eloquence is directed against the man, and the affairs of the State, are no otherwise the subject of his discourse, than as they are connected with the Actions of the man whom he so severely censures. From the tenor of the whole composition one would imagine that the Question upon which the Speech was delivered, was Whether Antony was a villain.
Crafts with me a great part of the evening. The subject of our Conversation, a casuistical question of morality.

Tuesday April 17th: 1792. The Court of Common Pleas, sits this day. I entered about half a dozen actions— More than I have ever done hitherto, but still very small. My business, has an aspect a very little more favourable than it has had; but owing rather to accident than any permanent cause, and there still remains for me abundant occasion for anxiety.— One action I this day settled, and received my fees from the deft: Beale dined with me: Mr: and Mrs: Smith likewise dined at the Doctor’s. I read before dinner a few pages in Espinasse, but not so attentively as I ought.— In the afternoon I began upon the 3d: Philippic, and read it first in the old french translation of DuRyer, but I had not time to go through with it for Mr: Madey, a french gentleman came in, and engaged me to write for him, a certain obligation of a singular nature, which has employed me the remainder of the afternoon; & which I have not yet finished.— Crafts with me most of the afternoon.

Friday April 20. 1792. Wednesday, not much done during the day; the evening, at club, at Mr: Bulfinch’s. Mr: Clarke read a very good Letter from Dr: Brown to him.— The conversation not remarkably interesting.— Yesterday, a day equally eventless. Pass’d the Evening at the Miss Mackay’s; a numerous company of young people. Some conversation, some music, and some cards.

This afternoon was partly employed in the melancholy office of performing the last duties to the remains of William Amory a young man, with whom I have spent many happy hours. He was born with a disposition to communicate enjoyment, and with a faculty of dispensing it to the highest degree. With a heart too susceptible of the blandishments of pleasure, and an understanding capable of the most exuberant cultivation, had he possessed resolution to improve his talents. But early habits of Dissipation and a series of imprudencies, imputable in the eye of impartial reason, only to a predominating and
uncontroulable love of pleasure, have embittered the last years of his life, and connected with his own misery, the wretchedness of others: at the age of 27, which was completed on the day of his Death, after a lingering consumption of more than two years duration, he has fallen, the victim of those Passions, which had they taken a happier direction, might have led him to honour, & opulence; to a venerable age, and to important utility in the world. He has left a widow under 21 to deplore an irreparable loss, and an infant daughter, as yet incapable of estimating the value of the treasure which she must never possess, in the tender and anxious sollicitude of paternal affection.— The instance is common of youth brought to an untimely end, by the vices to which that period of life is so peculiarly exposed, but perhaps the sacrifice at the shrine of Intemperate Enjoyment, was never an object more adorned with every amiable virtue, and Every pleasing accomplishment, than it was in the person of this unfortunate young man. Such amid all his infirmities, was the goodness of his Heart, and such the integrity of his Soul, that we may humbly hope, at the bar of eternal Heaven, Justice will soften into Mercy, and his errors will be forgiven in the favour of his virtues.

The subject is awful; to me it will be instructive; but it leads me into a train of Contemplation, in which the pen cannot follow my ideas—and besides the impressions upon my mind though deep enough upon the present occasion, yet upon paper would have very much the appearance of common place— It is late too, and I must therefore postpone further observations to another opportunity.— I have read not a little this day; but without any connection Law, Poetry Oratory, History, Latin, French, English, heaped up in chaotic confusion in my mind, leave no room for Reflection, and suggest nothing for Observation.
